data.title: Firm Civilian Control of Military Is Sought : Wahid Set to Shake Up Indonesia Armed Forces
data.meta_description: The recent suspension of General Wiranto from his cabinet security position has cleared the way for President Abdurrahman Wahid to press ahead with making the military a more professional force firmly under civilian control, according to Indonesian offic
data.text:
The recent suspension of General Wiranto from his cabinet security position has cleared the way for President Abdurrahman Wahid to press ahead with making the military a more professional force firmly under civilian control, according to Indonesian officials and other experts.

Mr. Wahid, in his capacity as supreme commander under the constitution, is expected to approve more than 40 changes soon in the top ranks of the armed forces, removing officers of suspect loyalty and consolidating his government's hold over the military.

He is also expected to reduce sharply the size of the army's special forces, a 6,000-member unit that is widely blamed for many human rights abuses in East Timor, Aceh and other parts of Indonesia.

In a further sign of change in the military, officials said that the army planned to relinquish all its seats in Parliament in the next elections, The Associated Press reported Friday.

The armed forces commander, Admiral Widodo Adisutjipto, told a special committee of legislators that the military wanted to give up the 38 seats it has reserved for its appointees in the 500-member Parliament.

He added that the military would remain neutral in the elections, scheduled for 2004.

General Wiranto was suspended by Mr. Wahid after he was implicated by an Indonesian inquiry into the wave of violence and destruction that followed East Timor's vote for independence from Indonesia last August.
